name: GJ 273
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 273 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 273 is a star with 0.29 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.29 times its radius. It is located 12.39 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 273 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 273 system


GJ 273 b

GJ 273 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 273 b is 2.89062 times the mass of Earth. At 2.89062 Earth masses, GJ 273 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 273 c

GJ 273 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 273 c is 1.17978 times the mass of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, GJ 273 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 273, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by La Silla Observatory.
